name: Wu Xing
shortDescription: Five Elements theory - the cyclical system of Wood, Fire, Earth, Metal, and Water
fullDescription: Wu Xing (‰∫îË°å, W«î X√≠ng, literally 'Five Phases' or 'Five Elements') is a fundamental framework in Chinese thought describing the dynamic interplay of five elemental forces: Wood (Êú®), Fire (ÁÅ´), Earth (Âúü), Metal (Èáë), and Water (Ê∞¥). Unlike Western elements, these are not static substances but active phases in constant transformation, interacting through generative (ÂâµÁîü) and destructive (Áõ∏Ââã) cycles. Wood feeds Fire, Fire creates Earth (ash), Earth bears Metal, Metal collects Water, Water nourishes Wood. This system underlies Chinese medicine, astrology, feng shui, martial arts, and cosmology.

mythologyContexts.usage: Framework for understanding natural cycles, medical diagnosis, feng shui, astrology (Chinese zodiac and destiny calculation), martial arts styles, and cosmic harmony. Used to analyze relationships, seasons, organs, emotions, and transformations

rituals.name: Medical Diagnosis
rituals.description: TCM uses Five Elements to understand organ relationships and treat imbalances

rituals.name: Feng Shui Application
rituals.description: Balancing elemental energies in spaces through colors, shapes, and materials

rituals.name: Astrological Calculation
rituals.description: Chinese astrology assigns elements to years, months, days, and hours

rituals.name: Martial Arts Forms
rituals.description: Xingyiquan (Form-Intent Boxing) based on Five Elements fighting principles

textReferences.context: Early description of the Five Elements and their properties
Extensive application of Five Elements in medical theory
Cosmological discussions of Five Elements relationships

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Wu Xing represents the dynamic, interconnected nature of reality where nothing exists in isolation. The generative cycle shows creative progression, while the destructive cycle maintains balance through control. Each element contains the potential for transformation into others, reflecting the constant flux of existence. The system embodies both harmony (when balanced) and conflict (when imbalanced).
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Wu Xing has influenced Chinese civilization for over 2,000 years, shaping medicine, philosophy, art, architecture, and daily life. The system appears in Chinese chess, cuisine (balancing flavors), color symbolism, and seasonal festivals. It remains central to Traditional Chinese Medicine, feng shui practice, and Chinese astrology.

japanese.meaning: five elements, used in Japanese philosophy and divination

korean.meaning: five elements, used in Korean traditional medicine

vietnamese.meaning: five elements, used in Vietnamese cosmology

originPoint.description: System formalized during Warring States period, building on earlier Zhou dynasty naturalist schools

firstAttestation.description: Hong Fan chapter of Shang Shu (Book of Documents) contains early systematic description

temporal.philosophicalContext: Naturalist school (Yinyang jia) systematized during Warring States, later integrated into Confucian cosmology
